channel.title: Using an IDE
channel.description:
I realize there are a lot of videos, tutorials, and other snippets around spoon-feeding people on how to set up a server in Eclipse, or any IDE. The thing is.. I've downloaded around four different sources whether it be hyperion, runesource, anything I've wanted to start working on and none of them have worked.
I understand how to set it up. I can practically tell you word for word, open new> java project> pick a name, only you'll see the name. Pick your source file> run- configurations> Find the main class, and arguments if needed.
The problem here is I continue to get the same error,
[code=java] java.net.BindException: Address already in use: bind [/code]
If I could, for once more, get practically spoon fed on how to fix this, I'd be immensely thankful.
Edit: Uninstalled an older version of Java I had and it started working, Thanks bl3nd for the reply.
Moderator can close. thanks!

item.title: Using an IDE
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Zymus:

In eclipse, go to the console output tab on the bottom, and on the right hand side, there should be a little computer symbol. Click the black arrow next to it and find one that doesn’t say [terminated]. Select that, click the red stop button.

This.

Also: If you are using uTorrent, you don’t need to “close” it. You just need to change the port from 43594 to, well, anything else. And then once the server is online again, set it back to 43594.

Read full topic

item.title: Using an IDE
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

In eclipse, go to the console output tab on the bottom, and on the right hand side, there should be a little computer symbol. Click the black arrow next to it and find one that doesn’t say [terminated]. Select that, click the red stop button.

item.title: Using an IDE
item.dc:creator: @Bl3nd Bl3nd
item.description:
@Bl3nd wrote:

[quote=“Adobe, post:3, topic:550039”][quote author=Bl3nd link=topic=668916.msg4473404#msg4473404 date=1424405963]
Another instance of a program is using the address. Close (if you have it) Utorrent or go into your task manager and force close something with the name javaw.
[/quote]

That’s what I thought it was, but I’ve closed every instance I’m running in Java.

I recently downloaded a 64 bit version of java, when I already had 32 bit of the same version, maybe that could be the problem?[/quote]

Uhh I wouldn’t think that would be the problem. Are there two servers running? Make sure haha

Read full topic

I recently downloaded a 64 bit version of java, when I already had 32 bit of the same version, maybe that could be the problem?
